detail.content: Carbon Cycle                      CARBON CYCLE                                 Image above obtained from http://www.cotf.edu/ete/modules/carbon/earthfire.html                Facts:           - Carbon (C) enters the  biosphere during photosynthesis:              CO2 + H2O ---> C6H12O6 + O2 + H2O          - Carbon is returned to the biosphere in cellular  respiration:              O2 +H2O + C6H12O6 ---> CO2 +H2O + energy          Amount of CO2 during the year:            - Every year there  is a measurable difference in the          concentration of atmospheric CO2 in phase with the seasons.          For example, in winter there is almost no photosynthesis          therefore there is a high concentration of CO2.          - During the growing season there is a measurable differnece in the          concentration of atmospheric CO2 over parts of each day. For          example, at sunrise photosynthesis begins with the uptake of CO2,          by afternoon plant respiration increases, at sunset photosynthesis          stops so the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere increases.            Human induced changes in the global carbon  cycle:          - The Earth is getting warmer.          - The 20th century has been the warmest in the last 600 years.          - This century is about 1 degree Fahrenheit warmer than last          century.          - The balance of evidence suggests that burning of fossil fuel          (eg. coal, oil, natural gas), which emits CO2 as a waste, is the          cause.          - CO2 is a "Green House" gas - it traps heat at the Earth's surface.          (H2O vapor and methane are also examples of green house gases)          Signs that the climate is warming:          - Plants start blooming 8 days earlier in spring than 11 years ago.          - Birds from the United Kingom lay eggs earlier.          - Buds on trees appear earlier and leaves fall later in the Northern          Hemisphere.          - Alaska, North West Canada, and Siberia have warmed up as          much as 5 degrees Fahrenheit in the last 30 years. Students learn how human activity has impacted the carbon cycle since the industrial revolution.     Engineering Connection   Engineering started to impact our life styles in different ways since the invention of the steam engine. Engines in their primitive designs were not as efficient as we see them work for us today, and worked by making a great amount of pollution. Studying the environment around us, it came to our attention that we have to design more efficiently, and more in harmony with the nature. By studying the natural cycles and noticing the reactions of nature to our activities, engineering designs are on a path of improvement, in many ways. Greener designs are mostly less expensive in a longer period of time.     Engineering Category    Efficient Engineering, Design patterns     Educational Standards   New York Science: 1.1     Pre-Requisite Knowledge   None     Learning Objectives   Students will be able to:   ●        Explain the Carbon Cycle   ●        Explain the impact of different forms of carbon to our climate   ●        Name the carbon pools on earth   ●        Explain the impact of human activity on the Carbon Cycle     Introduction/ Motivation:   Carbon impacts ecosystems in many ways, and imbalance in the carbon cycle has global consequences. Human activities have impacted the balance of the Carbon Cycle since the Industrial Revolution. The great increase in use of fossil fuels such as coal, which was used to heat water for the first steam engines and continues to be a major source of energy, has released a great amount of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.   The carbon cycle is the biogeochemical cycle by which carbon is exchanged among the terrestrial biosphere, pedosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere of the Earth. These spheres comprise the major carbon pools on earth. Carbon in the ocean is dissolved in water in the form of bicarbonate, and ocean organisms absorb carbon from the water and atmosphere.  Carbon is absorbed from the atmosphere by photosynthetic organisms in the biosphere and hydrosphere. Carbon in the forms of methane and carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere by biological organisms in the biosphere, pedosphere, and hydrosphere, and by human consumption of fossil fuels.   The atmosphere is thus one of the most dynamic carbon pools. The increase (or decrease) of carbon in the atmosphere affects carbon levels in the ocean, and affects global warming.     Vocabulary/Definitions         Biosphere   Regions of earth occupied by living organisms       Pedosphere   The outermost layer of the earth, composed of soil       Geosphere   The crust and outer mantle of the earth       Hydrosphere   All the water on the earth’s surface       Atmosphere   Gases surrounding the earth           Investigating Questions   ·            What are examples of carbon being transferred from one pool to another?   ·            Which parts of the carbon cycle can be affected by human activity? How?   ·            What are some of the consequences of the increase of carbon-base greenhouse gases in the atmosphere? Newton’s Laws of Motion Electricity Basics Geoengineering Power Storage in a Smart Grid Power Generation  Urban Infrastructure Earth’s Natural Cycles (Rock, Carbon, Water, Nitrogen) Water and Life Water Recycling and Treatment Recycling and Engineering Carbon Cycle Local, Whole, and Organic Foods Layout of City Food and Resources Green Infrastructure Global Ecosystems Soil Engineering  Transportation Modes of Transportation Traffic and Transportation Engineering Smart Transportation Smart Highways and Cars Intelligent Transportation Systems  Wireless Communications Introduction to Smart Wireless Network and Communications Engineering Space Based Wireless Communication  Blog Center for K12 STEM Education                                                              Carbon Cycle, City Food and Resources and Local, Whole and Organic Foods                      Leave a reply                             I learned about the Carbon Cycle, the process in which carbon is exchanged throughout the earth. Carbon cycles through the Biosphere, Pedosphere, Geosphere, Hydrosphere, and Atmosphere through respiration emissions, photosynthesis, and ocean uptake. Photoplankton absorbs carbon and transfers it through the sea’s ecosystem. I also learned about the difference between Local, Whole, and Organic foods. Local food is food made in the neighborhood. Whole food is food shipped from outside the state or country. Organic food is food without preservatives and pesticides. Finally, I learned about City food and resources, essentially, the things required or needed to create a functionally operating city. Markets, government , and reactions to disasters are important parts of a city as one provides food, leadership and ways to deal with problems we cannot control.
